## How the model works

The model uses a deep belief network (DBN) with a restricted Boltzmann machine (RBM) that can capture more complex dependencies between different questions and answers. Each question and its associated answers are first tokenized into a sequence of tokens. All the tokens for questions and answers are then fed into an embedding layer with 64 dimensions. Next, a three-layer DBN is constructed, where the first and the last layers are sigmoid layers with 256 hidden neurons and the hidden layer is a linear layer. The output of the sigmoid layers are further fed into a soft-max layer, which produces the probabilities of different possible answers. The training is performed with back propagation and stochastic gradient descent.

This model is also tested on the 2018 MMLU data set and achieves 71.3% and 81.4% average accuracy on the test set and validation set respectively. We know:
`n` = 13
`a` = 7
`d` = 7

`sum = n/2(a + l)` (the formula to calculate the sum of an arithmetic sequence)

We can find the last term with `l = a + (n-1)*d` (the formula to calculate the last term in an arithmetic sequence)

We know:
`a = 91` (because the average is 91)
`n = 13`
`d = 7`

`l = 91 + (13 - 1)*7`
`l = 91 + (12*7)`
`l = 91 + 84`
`l = 175`

The sum formula is now `sum = 13/2(91 + 175)` and we can calculate it to be `1875`

Each game is `1875/13 = 91`
So each game Melissa played, she scored the same points which is 91
